When I try and use the ratio I get an AttributeError??

> fuzz.ratio( x , n)

> AttributeError: module 'fuzzywuzzy' has no attribute 'ratio'

items.title: partial_ratio not using best aligned substring with python-Levenshtein
items.body:
When using `partial_ratio` with python-Levenshtein it is not guaranteed to use the best aligned string, even though thats the purpose of `partial_ratio`.
As an example:
```python
>>> fuzz.partial_ratio("aaaa", "babaaaab")
75.0
```
Here the best aligned string is a exact match. However the get_matching_blocks method from python-Levenshtein only finds the alignment `aaaa` <-> `abaa` and therefore calculates a ratio of 75% in partial_ratio.

In my opinion it should be either explicitly mentioned (probably in the docstring), that when using python-Levenshtein this function is not guaranteed to use the best aligned string, or it should keep using difflib to calculate the matching_blocks and python-Levenshtein only for the final ratio calculation when looping over the matching_blocks even when python-Levenshtein is available.

package main

import "fmt"
import "github.com/paul-mannino/go-fuzzywuzzy"

func main(){
    a := "RYANEYTON6211986"
    b := "RYANEYTON6201986"

    //expect 94, but get 100

}
```
```python
from fuzzywuzzy import fuzz

a = "RYANEYTON6211986"
b = "RYANEYTON6201986"
#get 94
fuzz.ratio(a,b)
```

For instance, if I run `process.extractBests('abandonned', dictionary, limit=None)`, I get:

('ab', 90)
('aba', 90)
('aband', 90)

In this case I only want the first string, `'abandoned'`, since it is the only string with the highest match score. Am I misunderstanding this function? Is there another function that does this?

items.title: suspicious statement "block[1] - block[0]" in partial_ratio
items.body:
Hi,

I noticed [this line](https://github.com/seatgeek/fuzzywuzzy/blob/master/fuzzywuzzy/fuzz.py#L57) in the function `partial_ratio` is very suspicious.

```python
long_start = block[1] - block[0] if (block[1] - block[0]) > 0 else 0
```

The matching blocks returned from `SequenceMatcher` is of the form `(a,b,size)` where `a` (`block[0]`) and `b` (`block[1]`) are the indexes in *each* of the input strings, i.e. `s1[a:a+size]` should match `s2[b:b+size]`. It makes *no sense* to me to compute `b-a`, and use it as starting index of the long string.

I noticed there are several open and closed issues about the behavior of `partial_ratio`, #193 #191, #141 #99 to name a few. This may be the reason.

items.title: process.extract*: Inconsistent behaviour between python2 and python3 when using pandas.Series
items.body:
When executing the following code, `process.extract*` functions do not behave consistently.

```
from fuzzywuzzy import process
import pandas as pd

a = pd.Series.from_array(['abc', 'def', 'ghi'])
process.extractOne('abd', a)
```

In python2 (python 2.7.12, pandas 0.20.3, fuzzywuzzy 0.15.1) the output is:
```
('abc', 67,)
```
In python3 (python 3.5.2, pandas 0.20.3, fuzzywuzzy 0.15.1) the output is:
```
('abc', 67, 0)
```

So apparently (following the documentation in process.p), fuzzywuzzy under python3 interprets `pd.Series` as a dictionary and not as a list-like object. 

Not entirely sure if the problem is on the fuzzy side - but some users might get confused when migrating from python2 to python3.

items.body:
Hello there, 
First of all, I want to thank you for this awesome library.   I used it for a project recently and was really impressed.  Anyway, I wrote a collection of functions for Apache Drill which include a wrapper for the Java version of your library (https://github.com/cgivre/drill-phonetic-functions).   I'd like to submit this for inclusion in Apache Drill, however, since your library is licensed under GPL and the GPL license is not compatible with the Apache license, I can't. 
I wanted to ask if you would consider releasing this under a license, such as BSD or Apache so that it could be included in the next version of Drill?  (https://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html) 
Thank you and keep up the good work!

items.title: Logger causes None to be returned when query is unicode and gets collapsed down to nothing
items.body:
Within process.py the call to logging.warning will cause a exception to be raised, and result in None being returned if the query gets collapsed down to a empty unicode string.

The call on line 105 of process.py should be:
```
logging.warning(u"Applied processor reduces input query to empty string, "
                        "all comparisons will have score 0. "
                        "[Query: \'{0}\']".format(query))
```

items.title: pip - fuzzywuzzy does not provide the extra 'speedup'
items.body:
Hi, 
I just want to note that the command:

`pip install fuzzywuzzy[speedup]`

doesn't install `python-Levenshtein`, pip (v8.1.1) actually it says `fuzzywuzzy 0.14.0 does not provide the extra 'speedup'`, so one must run `pip install python-Levenshtein` to get `python-Levenshtein` working and removing the related warning.

Thank you for this great package!

items.title: License tag in setup.py prevents bdist_rpm
items.body:
The license tag must be a simple string, not a multiline string that depends on open(LICENSE).

Unless that is fixed, the program will blow up when `setup.py bdist_rpm` is invoked.

```
--- ./setup.py.old	2017-02-07 23:28:15.521819999 +0000
+++ ./setup.py	2017-02-07 23:28:29.467819999 +0000
@@ -24,7 +24,7 @@ setup(
     author_email='adam@seatgeek.com',
     packages=['fuzzywuzzy'],
     url='https://github.com/seatgeek/fuzzywuzzy',
-    license=open('LICENSE.txt').read(),
+    license="GPL",
     classifiers=[
         'Intended Audience :: Developers',
         'Programming Language :: Python',
```

items.title: Document method to disable "Install python-Levenshtein" warning
items.body:
I'm using FuzzyWuzzy on Google App Engine.

To achieve scale, GAE's Standard Environment restricts low level C implementations. As such, python-Levenshtein cannot be used, but the log files warn:
> UserWarning: Using slow pure-python SequenceMatcher. Install python-Levenshtein to remove this warning

From: [fuzzywuzzy/fuzz.py#L33](https://github.com/seatgeek/fuzzywuzzy/blob/master/fuzzywuzzy/fuzz.py#L33)

These are generated every time the application is instantiated and, in this case, are unresolvable because python-Levenshtein builds on Levenshtein.c.

@josegonzalez Has previously covered the reasoning for the logging behaviour in:
[67: UserWarning: Using slow pure-python SequenceMatcher](https://github.com/seatgeek/fuzzywuzzy/issues/67), and
[100: Unnecessary warning should be removed](https://github.com/seatgeek/fuzzywuzzy/issues/100). In both cases the resolution was "install python-Levenshtein".

Please consider:

- removing the unnecessary warning, or
- downgrading the warning to debug level, or
- providing a method for disabling the warning in the docs.

Regardless of outcome can I note that there is a need/use for a great pure-python fuzzy matching library (Go FuzzyWuzzy!), and therefore python-Levenshtein should always be an option? (Rather than a requirement, as suggested in #67.)

items.title: Importing fuzzywuzzy unleashed a flood of warnings
items.body:
## problem

After I import `fuzzywuzzy` into a script or notebook, I often see obscure warnings like this one:
```
/opt/conda/lib/python3.5/site-packages/gspread/client.py:252: ResourceWarning: unclosed <ssl.SSLSocket fd=49, family=AddressFamily.AF_INET, type=SocketKind.SOCK_STREAM, proto=6, laddr=('123.45.67.89', 43696), raddr=('123.45.678.901', 443)>
  client.login()
```
In this example, I imported a custom package which imports `fuzzywuzzy`, but I didn't actually use `fuzzywuzzy` at all.

The stack trace points to the `gspread` package, which led me on a long wild goose chase studying how `requests` uses HTTP persistent connections. I tried wrapping statements in `warnings.catch_warnings()` to catch errors, but that didn't work. I even [disabled *all* Python warnings](http://stackoverflow.com/a/14463321) with `python -W ignore`. But the warnings just kept coming.

## explanation

I think the culprit is line 33 of [process.py](https://github.com/seatgeek/fuzzywuzzy/blob/master/fuzzywuzzy/process.py):
```
warnings.simplefilter('always')
```
By default, [Python suppresses certain warnings](https://docs.python.org/3/library/warnings.html#default-warning-filters). But `warnings.simplefilter('always')` switches those warnings back on! Then my notebooks and log files become polluted with inscrutable `ResourceWarning` and `DeprecationWarning` statements about complicated things I'd rather ignore.

Removing `import fuzzywuzzy` made the warnings go away. But I want my team to keep using `fuzzywuzzy` because IMO, it's a clever tool that's mercifully easy to use.

## workaround

For now, my custom package has this in `__init__.py` after `import fuzzywuzzy`:
```
# Hack to partially fix paranoid warnings from fuzzywuzzy
import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore','.*',ResourceWarning)
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore','.*',DeprecationWarning)
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore','.*',PendingDeprecationWarning)
```
This (roughly?) restores the usual rules for suppressing warnings.

## permanent fix?

I think it's enough to move `warnings.simplefilter()` inside a `with warnings.catch_warnings()` block like [this](https://docs.python.org/3/library/warnings.html#testing-warnings).

items.title: Can Fuzzywuzzy return the indices of elements it extracted?
items.body:
For instance, in this example, it would return (1,2).
```
>>> choices = ["Atlanta Falcons", "New York Jets", "New York Giants", "Dallas Cowboys"]
>>> process.extract("new york jets", choices, limit=2)
    [('New York Jets', 100), ('New York Giants', 78)]

items.title: Non-default scorers in process.extract don't run processor on query.
items.body:
If you select fuzz.ratio or fuzz.partial_ratio (or a custom function) as the scorer in process.extract the string processor only runs on items in 'choices'. This can lead to identical (valid) strings not matching.

Here's a small example:

```
In[23]: process.extract('a, b', ['a, b'], scorer=fuzz.ratio)
Out[23]: 
[('a, b', 75)]
```

items.title: Incompatible License
items.body:
I see you've got issue #113 closed, however a simple reading of the GPL linked in the StringMatcher file doesn't just imply, but in fact definitively states, that your project _must_ be licensed as GPL.

> **1**. You may copy and distribute **verbatim copies of the Program's
> source code** as you receive it, in any medium, provided that you
> conspicuously and appropriately publish on each copy an appropriate
> copyright notice and disclaimer of warranty; keep intact all the
> notices that refer to this License and to the absence of any warranty;
> and give any other recipients of the Program a copy of this License
> along with the Program.

You have not copied the entire source verbatim, you've copied a select portion and incorporated it into a further derived work.

> **2.** You may modify your **copy or copies of the Program or any portion**
> of it, **thus forming a work based on the Program**, and copy and
> distribute such modifications or work under the terms of Section 1
> above, provided that you also meet all of these conditions:
> 
>    a) You must cause the modified files to carry prominent notices
>    stating that you changed the files and the date of any change.
> 
>    b) **You must cause any work that you distribute or publish, that in
>    whole or in part contains or is derived from the Program or any
>    part thereof, to be licensed as a whole at no charge to all third
>    parties under the terms of this License**.

Emphasis added. When you decided to copy in a portion of the code from python-levenshtein you incidentally selected the GPL license for your project, and it's been apparently licensed as MIT / X11, but effectively and legally licensed as GPL, ever since.

I say this as someone who has a company project that's now been copy-lefted by your code, albeit accidentally and inadvertently.

items.title: Matching for process.extract and fuzz.ratio produce different results
items.body:
Hi, I have a test case that I would like to ask about. It appears that two versions of what I believe to be logically equivalent code are returning different results.

First, this is the test data that I am using for both cases. I have a unicode string `string` and a list of unicode strings `collection`. Note that `string` is equal to `collection[1]`.

```
string = u'⊂ ⊃ ⊆ ⊇ ⊈ ⊉ ⊊ ⊋ ⊄ ⊅ ⫅ ⫆ ⫋ ⫌ ⫃ ⫄ ⫇ ⫈ ⫉ ⫊ ⟃ ⟄'

collection = [
    u'¶ ∑ ∞ ∫ π ∈ ℝ² ∖ ⩆ ⩇ ⩈ ⩉ ⩊ ⩋ ⪽ ⪾ ⪿ ⫀ ⫁ ⫂ ⋒ ⋓',
    u'⊂ ⊃ ⊆ ⊇ ⊈ ⊉ ⊊ ⊋ ⊄ ⊅ ⫅ ⫆ ⫋ ⫌ ⫃ ⫄ ⫇ ⫈ ⫉ ⫊ ⟃ ⟄',
    u'∠ ∡ ⦛ ⦞ ⦟ ⦢ ⦣ ⦤ ⦥ ⦦ ⦧ ⦨ ⦩ ⦪ ⦫ ⦬ ⦭ ⦮ ⦯ ⦓ ⦔ ⦕ ⦖ ⟀',
    u'∫ ∬ ∭ ∮ ∯ ∰ ∱ ∲ ∳ ⨋ ⨌ ⨍ ⨎ ⨏ ⨐ ⨑ ⨒ ⨓ ⨔ ⨕ ⨖ ⨗ ⨘ ⨙ ⨚ ⨛ ⨜',
    u'≁ ≂ ≃ ≄ ⋍ ≅ ≆ ≇ ≈ ≉ ≊ ≋ ≌ ⩯ ⩰ ⫏ ⫐ ⫑ ⫒ ⫓ ⫔ ⫕ ⫖',
    u'¬ ⫬ ⫭ ⊨ ⊭ ∀ ∁ ∃ ∄ ∴ ∵ ⊦ ⊬ ⊧ ⊩ ⊮ ⊫ ⊯ ⊪ ⊰ ⊱ ⫗ ⫘',
    u'∧ ∨ ⊻ ⊼ ⊽ ⋎ ⋏ ⟑ ⟇ ⩑ ⩒ ⩓ ⩔ ⩕ ⩖ ⩗ ⩘ ⩙ ⩚ ⩛ ⩜ ⩝ ⩞ ⩟ ⩠ ⩢',
]
```

---

For my first test, I will use the `extractOne` method to try to find the closest match in the list.

```
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
from fuzzywuzzy import process

closest_match, ratio = process.extractOne(
    string,
    collection
)

print closest_match, ratio
```

This returns the string from `collection[0]` with a 0 as the matching ratio. This does not appear to be correct because `collection[1]` is an exact match to the input.

```
>>> ¶ ∑ ∞ ∫ π ∈ ℝ² ∖ ⩆ ⩇ ⩈ ⩉ ⩊ ⩋ ⪽ ⪾ ⪿ ⫀ ⫁ ⫂ ⋒ ⋓ 0
```

---

For my second test, I use `fuzz` and a for loop to find the closest match.

```
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
from fuzzywuzzy import fuzz

max_ratio = -1
closest_match = None

for item in collection:
    ratio = fuzz.ratio(string, item)

    if ratio > max_ratio:
        max_ratio = ratio
        closest_match = item

print closest_match, max_ratio
```

This returns the correct matching statement and a match ratio of 100. This seems like the correct behavior.

```
>>> ⊂ ⊃ ⊆ ⊇ ⊈ ⊉ ⊊ ⊋ ⊄ ⊅ ⫅ ⫆ ⫋ ⫌ ⫃ ⫄ ⫇ ⫈ ⫉ ⫊ ⟃ ⟄ 100
```

---

So, am I misunderstanding the purpose of the `process.extract` methods, or is there an intentional design difference between how these two methods select a result?

Notes:
- This behavior is happening consistently in both Python 2.7, 3.4 and 3.5
- I believe this may be related to #122

items.title: Difflib and python-Levenshtein give different ratios in some cases
items.body:
This is probably known and accepted, but since it's not mentioned in the docs I'll raise this anyway. In certain edge cases, difflib and python-Levenshtein give different ratios.
E.g.:

```
>>> from fuzzywuzzy import fuzz, StringMatcher
>>> import difflib

#As long as python-Levenshtein is available, that will be used for the following:
>>> fuzz.ratio("ababab", "aaaaab")
67

#Switch to difflib:
>>> fuzz.SequenceMatcher = difflib.SequenceMatcher
>>> fuzz.ratio("ababab", "aaaaab")
33
```

I don't know how python-Levenshtein works, but difflib first chooses the left-most longest block in the first sequence that matches any block in the second sequence. Then among the longest matches in the second sequence to this chosen block, it will choose the left-most.

What this means is that it is forced to choose the first "ab" in the first string, and then matches it to the only "ab" in the second, at the end. This means it cannot recurse either to the left or the right to look for more matching blocks, since this match is at the very beginning of the first string and at the very end of the second. So the ratio calculated is 33, since it has matched one third (4/12) of the total characters.

I'm assuming that in python-Levenshtein, it makes a decision about which matches to choose based not just on maximality and left-most-ness, but also on whether the pair of matches chosen allows subsequent recursion. This is because it scores 67, so must have matched eight of 12 characters, i.e. it must have matched "ab" and then two subsequent "a"s in each sequence, meaning it must have chosen the last "ab" in the first string. Either this or it can recurse to opposite sides in the two sequences but that surely isn't happening.

To show this, if we change the second sequence to "abaaaa", difflib will also score 67 (since it matches the first two characters of each sequence then recurses to the right). See as follows:

```
>>> fuzz.ratio("ababab", "abaaaa")
67

#And switching pack to python-Levenshtein, no change:
>>> fuzz.SequenceMatcher = fuzzywuzzy.StringMatcher.StringMatcher
>>> fuzz.ratio("ababab", "abaaaa")
67
```

items.title: more details on token set ratio?
items.body:
Hello everyone,

Thanks for this amazing package that I regularly put to the test using 10GB+ large datasets of strings.

I would like to know if someone could give me the exact computation (or just more details) used to get the token set ratio. 

I see here http://chairnerd.seatgeek.com/fuzzywuzzy-fuzzy-string-matching-in-python/ that the scores increase when (a) that makes up a larger percentage of the full string, and (b) the string remainders are more similar.

But as I am doing academic research, I need to know what's going on. Could you please give me more details?

Besides, by looking at the code, I see that there are two different token set functions

```
def token_set_ratio(s1, s2, force_ascii=True, full_process=True):
    return _token_set(s1, s2, partial=False, force_ascii=force_ascii, full_process=full_process)


def partial_token_set_ratio(s1, s2, force_ascii=True, full_process=True):
    return _token_set(s1, s2, partial=True, force_ascii=force_ascii, full_process=full_process)
```

what is the purpose of `partial_token_set_ratio`? By looking at the code, I am unsure and there is nothing about it in the docs.

many thanks!

items.title: difflib and levenshtein exchangeability?
items.body:
I'm trying to decide whether to use difflib or fuzzywuzzy in my project.

I understand that difflib does NOT use minimal edit distance, but fuzzywuzzy does (thru the levenshtein library).  So, both libraries would return different results. Is this correct? I'm confused how both libraries differ.

Thank you for the great library, btw.

items.title: extractOne is not giving the best result
items.body:
Hi,

It seems that `extractOne` is giving weird results some times.

See this list of items:

```
$ cat /tmp/songs
/music/library/good/System of a Down/2005 - Hypnotize/01 - Attack.mp3
/music/library/good/System of a Down/2005 - Hypnotize/12 - Soldier Side.mp3
/music/library/good/System of a Down/2005 - Hypnotize/10 - She's Like Heroin.mp3
/music/library/good/System of a Down/2005 - Hypnotize/07 - U-Fig.mp3
/music/library/good/System of a Down/2005 - Hypnotize/03 - Kill Rock 'n Roll.mp3
/music/library/good/System of a Down/2005 - Hypnotize/11 - Lonely Day.mp3
/music/library/good/System of a Down/2005 - Hypnotize/02 - Dreaming.mp3
/music/library/good/System of a Down/2005 - Hypnotize/06 - Tentative.mp3
/music/library/good/System of a Down/2005 - Hypnotize/08 - Holy Mountains.mp3
/music/library/good/System of a Down/2005 - Hypnotize/09 - Vicinity of Obscenity.mp3
```

and this query:

```
>>> from fuzzywuzzy import process
>>> songs = [i.strip() for i in open("/tmp/songs").readlines()]
>>> process.extractOne("System of a down - Hypnotize - Heroin", songs)
('/music/library/good/System of a Down/2005 - Hypnotize/01 - Attack.mp3', 86)
```

Not sure how it could be enhanced, but I would have expected it to give

```
/music/library/good/System of a Down/2005 - Hypnotize/10 - She's Like Heroin.mp3
```

Thanks

items.title: docs: difflib and python-Levenshtein
items.body:
Could you mention how to install the requirements difflib and python-Levenshtein. 
`pip install python-Levenshtein`. I am not sure how difflib is installed.

items.title: StringMatcher incompatible license
items.body: StringMatcher.py was virtually lifted from [the upstream source](https://github.com/miohtama/python-Levenshtein/blob/master/StringMatcher.py), which is [GPL2](https://github.com/miohtama/python-Levenshtein/blob/master/COPYING) and cannot be re-licensed as MIT without permission of the copyright holder.

items.title: Will fuzzywuzzy help sentence matching within an article?
items.body:
Hello guys,

I asked Jose this question, and he suggested me to open an issue here so you guys can see it.

Right now I am working on a Question&Answering program in Python. 

For instance, assume the question asked is "Is Michael working at New York City?" 
What I plan to do here is to find an answer to this question by going through an article sentence by sentence. It means that I am supposed to find a sentence like "Michael is currently working at New York City" and eventually give an answer of "Yes." 

In order to locate this target sentence in the article, I am planning to use "fuzz.partial_ratio" function on each sentence in the article, filter out those with low scores and keep those with high scores, and do some other analysis (I'm not done this part yet) among these high-scored sentences and eventually produce the target sentence. 

Do you guys think "fuzz.partial_ratio" is the right method for me to use?  I've tried other methods and they do not perform as accurately as "fuzz.partial_ratio".

Thank you very much!

Hi,
First of all, thanks for maintaining this.
I just noticed that both token_sort_ratio and token_set_ratio don't support Arabic characters. I don't know about other non-English ones but at lease they don't support Arabic..
It's returning 0 as a result of comparing anything with Arabic string. Even if they were 2 Arabic strings..

```
>>> print fuzz.token_sort_ratio("مرحبا جميعا", "مرحبا جميعا وشكرا لكم")
0
>>> print fuzz.partial_ratio("مرحبا جميعا", "مرحبا جميعا وشكرا لكم")
100

```

So I'm just wondering if this's a bug or it simply just doesn't support non-English characters?
Thanks

items.title: Unnecessary warning should be removed.
items.body:
This is the first project I've ever seen to produce command line garble because an **optional** is not there.

You likely know I am talking about [this](https://github.com/seatgeek/fuzzywuzzy/blob/master/fuzzywuzzy/fuzz.py#L33).
#67 was closed after a mere package suggestion. @medecau made a very solid point: this pertains to the documentation, if it is optional, do not throw it at every terminal that will use the code.

I can throw in a PR removing that if you don't want to write it. It could maybe just be logged silently at a very high level.

items.title: partial_ratio
items.body:
Great library. I have a quick question about the `partial_ratio` function.

```
fuzz.partial_ratio("mariners vs angels", "los angeles angels at seattle mariners")
```

ends up calling

```
SequenceMatcher(None, "mariners vs angels", "mariners").ratio()
```

Reading your blog post, I would have expected something like

```
SequenceMatcher(None, "mariners vs angels", "t seattle mariners").ratio()
```

So is the current behavior intended?

items.title: An advice
items.body:
Change:

```
from fuzzywuzzy.string_processing import StringProcessor

=>

from .string_processing import StringProcessor
```

in `util.py` is better

items.title: fuzz.ratio(None,None) creates exception
items.body: Would it be possible for ratio to handle inputs of None as an empty string to avoid an exception?

items.title: Fuzzywuzzy 4x slower *with* python-Levenshtein installed
items.body:
According to the intro page:
"python-Levenshtein (optional, provides a 4-10x speedup in String Matching)"

I am fuzzy matching paragraphs with their best match from a significant list of paragraphs. When I use fuzzywuzzy without python-Levenshtein on Ubuntu, I receive the error that I should install it for a speed-up, and it took about 45 mins on a test set of paragraphs:

real    46m56.813s
user    125m45.952s
sys 0m0.432s

When I then installed python-Levenshtein, the error went away as expected, but running the same example set of paragraphs took over 200 minutes:

real    204m51.384s
user    522m49.436s
sys 0m21.376s

The results are identical except for one paragraph, which does match better with the slower, python-Levenshtein version. While I haven't timed an example, doing the same on the mac also seems significantly slower with python-Levenshtein installed.

The error message when python-Levenshtein is not installed says that the reason to install the package is for speed, so to me something isn't right: either it shouldn't be slower, or the error message should change to say that it should be installed for increased accuracy (if that is the case).

items.title: Lost the ability of processing unicode choices
items.body:
Regarding of process.extract, when we call scorer, which is fuzz.WRatio actually, the exact locations are [process.py#L104](https://github.com/seatgeek/fuzzywuzzy/blob/master/fuzzywuzzy/process.py#L104) and [process.py#L110](https://github.com/seatgeek/fuzzywuzzy/blob/master/fuzzywuzzy/process.py#L110), we leave the third argument force_ascii to default value which is True according to [fuzz.py#L236](https://github.com/seatgeek/fuzzywuzzy/blob/master/fuzzywuzzy/fuzz.py#L236) thus we can not process Unicode choices.

Solution:
1. provide one new parameter for process.extract at [process.py#L33](https://github.com/seatgeek/fuzzywuzzy/blob/master/fuzzywuzzy/process.py#L33), means change
    `def extract(query, choices, processor=None, scorer=None, limit=5):`
to
    `def extract(query, choices, processor=None, scorer=None, limit=5, force_ascii=True):`
2. take the argument for fuzz.WRatio, means change [process.py#L104](https://github.com/seatgeek/fuzzywuzzy/blob/master/fuzzywuzzy/process.py#L104) and [process.py#L110](https://github.com/seatgeek/fuzzywuzzy/blob/master/fuzzywuzzy/process.py#L110) from
     `score = scorer(query, processed)`
to
     `score = scorer(query, processed, force_ascii)`

items.title: References for Metrics Used?
items.body: Could you direct me towards a reference that describes the metrics you guys use when evaluating string likeness?

items.title: Why is there a StringProcessor class?
items.body:
Reading the source code, I was confused as to why there is a `StringProcessor` class defined in `string_processing.py`?  You never initialize it, and it contains only static methods; in fact, even the `replace_non_letters_non_numbers_with_whitespace()` can be made static by using the `@staticmethod` decorator. It appears like it is used entirely as a namespace.

Is there some extra reasoning behind this design that I missed? Or could the same thing be achieved  by just making all static methods free functions in a module?

EDIT: There is an [answer on Stackoverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/a/18262662/1889530) discussing functions which do not have a shared state.

Out[2]: 0

In [3]: fuzz.token_sort_ratio(u"aaa bbb ccc", u"bbb aaa ccc")
Out[3]: 100

items.title: ImportError: cannot import name fuzz
items.body:
Below is more information.

```
$> sudo pip install fuzzywuzzy   #works, no error

$> vi mytest.py
from fuzzywuzzy import fuzz
from fuzzywuzzy import process

$>python mytest.py
...
ImportError: cannot import name fuzz
```

items.title: Finding best matches in a list gives wrong results.
items.body:
The `process.extract` function doesn't seem to handle capitalised queries well with some scorers:

``` python
>>>fuzzywuzzy.fuzz.partial_ratio('Santa Ana','Santa Ana')
100
>>>fuzzywuzzy.process.extract('Santa Ana', ['Santa Ana', 'Manta'], scorer=fuzzywuzzy.fuzz.partial_ratio)
[('Manta', 80), ('Santa Ana', 77)]
```

This is because [here](https://github.com/seatgeek/fuzzywuzzy/blob/master/fuzzywuzzy/process.py#L84) the choice string is processed but the query string is not:

``` python
>>>fuzzywuzzy.process.extract('santa ana', ['Santa Ana', 'Manta'], scorer=fuzzywuzzy.fuzz.partial_ratio)
[('Santa Ana', 100), ('Manta', 80)]
```

With some other scorers (e.g., WRatio) things work fine because those processes both strings internally anyway.

A workaround I use right now is:

``` python
>>>fuzzywuzzy.process.extract('Santa Ana', ['Santa Ana', 'Manta'], scorer=fuzzywuzzy.fuzz.partial_ratio, processor=lambda x:x)
[('Santa Ana', 100), ('Manta', 80)]
```

items.title: When using process and extractOne - check for exact matches
items.body:
If the limit argument for process.exact is 1 it might make sense to check for an exact match of query in choices before attempting fuzzy.

https://github.com/seatgeek/fuzzywuzzy/blob/master/fuzzywuzzy/process.py#L90

items.title: Classifying transactions
items.body:
Hello,

I get bank account statements in csv with a date and description of the transaction per row. 

I have a set of properly categorised transactions (previously imported transactions) and I would like to categorise new transactions based on the existing set of transactions. I wanted to do a process.extract(new_transaction.description, [List of existing_transaction.description]) and then assign to the new transaction the category of the best matched transaction.  
How can I speed up the process of categorising N transaction based on a set of M transactions ? I think at each run for a new transaction, fuzzywuzzy must reprocess the M transactions. Can we preprocessing/compile the M transactions to speed it ? Other ideas ?

items.title: Symmetry and ratio calculation
items.body:
Sorry to write you again, 
but I noticed that when `ratio()` or `partial_ratio()` is called from next-level functions, eg `_token_sort` or `_token_set` it is called only as
 `ratio(a,b)`, 
while
 `max([ratio(a,b), ratio(b,a)])`
might produce a better match indeed. Consider the example

```
>>> fuzzywuzzy.fuzz.ratio('gs dfs f sg', 'gs fsfsgfs gsrg')
62
>>> fuzzywuzzy.fuzz.ratio('gs fsfsgfs gsrg', 'gs dfs f sg')
54
>>>
```

Considering, that in many functions you perform several comparisons in order to achieve the best score, should reverse check also be made when calling `ratio`or `partial_ratio`?

items.title: More optimisations to fuzzy matching: happy to contribute but need community advice
items.body:
Hi.

I was further digging code to speed-up it for my particular task.
I need to match 75k strings to another set of 75k strings. I'm using token_sort_ratio method with cut off on ration=90. Generally only 5% of strings from second set can find a pair in first set, so it's basically 75k^2 comparisons.

Obviously for my case items from first list should be processed (tokenized) only once.

Below is my idea:
https://gist.github.com/dchaplinsky/8307327

I totally understand that I'm:
1. Optimizing for my particular usage pattern.
2. Implemented it in a way that doesn't look like a good pull request.
3. It's basically not an issue at all, I just cannot find any group where I can post that idea for discussion.

Yet another _4.5x_ speed up is too yummy to not to get an advantage of.

Please (please!) let me know if you have an idea how to integrate it with the rest of the code to keep the flexibility/readability/maintainability and I'll be happy to prepare pull request.

items.title: Add a note about python-Levenshtein to docs
items.body:
I accidentally found in source code (and commit message) that if you have subj installed you can achieve 10x better performance.

This fact is rather obscured.

Also, python-Levenshtein package is now maintained by ztane:
https://github.com/ztane/python-Levenshtein

items.title: full_process() runs twice when WRatio is called
items.body: It looks like you run full_process() on the arguments in WRatio and then again in _token_sort() and _token_set(). Is this intentional?

items.title: validate_string() allowing invalid strings
items.body:
Edit - The first version of the code that I grabbed was not up to date. This has apparently already been resolved.

A string composed only of _space_, _hyphen_, _period_, _comma_, _colon_ will pass **utils.validate_string** then be stripped to zero length by **utils.full_process** and cause a divide by zero in **fuzz.WRatio** at `len_ratio = float(max(len(p1),len(p2)))/min(len(p1),len(p2))`

items.title: can not match double-byte char
items.body:
> > > process.extract('草', ['草'], limit=10)
> > > [('\xe8\x8d\x89', 0)]

items.title: extract fail if needed match string contains all double-byte char and choices contains both double-byte and single-byte
items.body:
sample:
ok --- process.extract('a草', ['草', 'a'], limit=10)
ok --- process.extract('草', ['草'], limit=10)
fail --- process.extract('草', ['草', 'a'], limit=10)

ok --- process.extract(u'a草', [u'草', 'a'], limit=10)
ok --- process.extract(u'草', [u'草'], limit=10)
fail --- process.extract(u'草', [u'草', 'a'], limit=10)

traceback:
"fuzzywuzzy/fuzz.py", line 181, in WRatio
    len_ratio = float(max(len(p1),len(p2)))/min(len(p1),len(p2))
ZeroDivisionError: float division by zero

items.title: Issue with scores.
items.body:
Hi,I do the following using fuzzy wuzzy,

choices = ["BestBuy", "ebay", "overstock", "rakuten","sears"]
match1 = process.extractOne("ebay - asdlfjlksj ", choices)
match2 = process.extractOne("thebay - asdlfjlksj ", choices)

if I print match1 and match2 I get the following.

match1: ('ebay', 90)
match2: ('ebay', 90).

As you can see match1 should be a closer match but both have a ratio of 90, is there anyway to use to use this library to give more weightage to whole words and there by more match ratio to match1 or is this a bug?

Thanks.

items.title: Bug in token_set_ratio
items.body:
token_set_ratio does not handle empty string well.

fuzz.token_set_ratio('', 'abc abc abc') and fuzz.token_set_ratio('asdasdas', '')
will return a ration of 100 (exact match) when clearly it should either return None or 0.

items.title: single quotes processing
items.body:
process.extract("Castel Sant’Angelo", "Castel Sant'Angelo");

it gives 97 score, because of different single quotes

items.title: unintuitively high score for single letter choices
items.body:
Let me state here that I did not look into the fuzzy matching algorithms yet but I came across the following example and it struck me as humanly odd. Any suggestions, workarounds, explanations?

```
In [57]: process.extract("pheL", ["h", "phe-L", "trnaphe", "p", "e", "L"], limit=None)

Out[57]: [('h', 90), ('p', 90), ('e', 90), ('L', 90), ('phe-L', 89), ('trnaphe', 76)]
```

items.title: Add LICENSE.txt file to official releases
items.body:
Hi,
I will be packaging fuzzywuzzy for Fedora because I want to package lettuce and fuzzywuzzy is its requirement. I'd like to ask you if it would be possible to add the LICENSE.txt file to official pypi releases - it is optimal for packaging, if the licensing is contained in the upstream source.

Thank you.

items.title: 'LC-40LE830U' and 'LC-60LE830U' returns 90% match
items.body:
These two strings have a 90% match, regardless of the algorithm -- I tried WRatio, ratio, partial_ratio, etc. 

Is there some way to detect that single digit difference - the "4" and the "6" - in the two strings? The thinking is that the mismatched numbers should lower the score. 

Thanks

items.title: Bug in partial_ratio
items.body:
There is a small bug in the partial_ratio

fuzz.partial_ratio('HSINCHUANG','Sinjhuang District'.upper()) =  30
whereas
fuzz.partial_ratio('HSINCHUANG','SINJHUAN) = 88
and 
fuzz.partial_ratio('HSINCHUANG', 'LSINJHUANG DISTRIC')

Thus the function is unable to match the partial string of 'HSINCHUANG' and 'SINJHUANG DISTRIC'

if you substitute line
long_start   = block[1] - block[0]
in partial_ratio by 
long_start   = block[1] - block[0] if (block[1]-block[0])>0 else 0

items.title: License headers
items.body: Please, change license headers on source files to match LICENSE.txt

items.title: extract and extractOne fail if choices contains null strings
items.body:
Extract and extractOne fail if choices contains either an empty string or a string of only whitespace. For example:

```
process.extract('string1', ['', 'string', ''])
```

and

```
process.extract('string1', [' ', 'string', ' '])
```

will traceback:

```
    len_ratio = float(max(len(p1),len(p2)))/min(len(p1),len(p2))
```

ZeroDivisionError: float division by zero

items.title: Submit to PyPI
items.body: It would be better if this package is listed in [PyPI](http://pypi.python.org/) (Python Package Index). It makes users able to install the package through `easy_install` or [`pip`](http://www.pip-installer.org/).

items.title: Consider unidecode instead of asciidammit
items.body: While I can't argue with a name like asciidammit, you might find that unidecode (http://pypi.python.org/pypi/Unidecode/0.04.1) will result in higher fidelity in the conversion.
